translated: Jingxi explains it with the Fuxing (Auxiliary Practice). The catalog says:
Our school has three kinds of Calming and Contemplation.
The first is called gradual.
It refers to understanding suddenly but practicing gradually.
This is the Chan Pāramitā.
The second is called indeterminate.
It refers to sudden understanding.
The practice may be sudden or gradual.
This is the Six Subtle Gates.
Third, the perfect and sudden.
It refers to both understanding and practice being sudden.
This is the Mohe Zhiguan.
These three types of calming and contemplation differ in their suitability for different capacities.

Gushan.
At the age of twenty-one.
He began to study under Master Qing of Fengxian.
And after two years, Fengxian passed away.
He then went to Gushan, closed the door, and raised his illness.
At the age of forty-seven, he passed away.
In twenty-four years.
He wrote one hundred and twenty fascicles.
How diligent!
Baoyun Guanyin Sutra Commentary Record Shizhi says:
